title: WeWork founder steps down as CEO
text:
It's the end of the line for the controversial CEO and founder of office-sharing start-up WeWork.

Adam Neumann on Tuesday agreed to step down as CEO of parent firm We Company but will stay on as non-executive chairman of the board.

He also agreed to give up majority voting control.

Neumann had been blamed for overseeing questionable corporate governance practices, which caused WeWork's valuation to plummet as it prepared for an IPO that has since been put on the shelf.

He even lost the backing of major investor SoftBank, according to earlier reports, which stood to lose billions if the IPO went ahead with a market value as low as $10 billion.

Financial backers still hope to pull off a market debut but questions remain about WeWork's business model of taking on long-term real estate leases and then renting out space in short-term rentals. Investors fear WeWork will have a hard time ever turning a profit, especially if the economy falters, leaving the company with an abundance of unoccupied office space.

Neumann is being replaced by two co-CEOS on an interim basis.
description:
It's the end of the line for the controversial CEO and founder of office-sharing start-up WeWork. 
              Adam Neumann on Tuesday agreed to step down as CEO of parent firm We Company but will stay on as non-executive chairman of the board. 
              He also agreed to give up majority voting control. 
              Neumann had been blamed for overseeing questionable corporate governance practices, which caused WeWork's valuation to plummet as it prepared for an IPO that has since been put on the shelf. 
              He even lost the backing of major investor SoftBank, according to earlier reports, which stood to lose billions if the IPO went ahead with a market value as low as $10 billion. 
              Financial backers still hope to pull off a market debut but questions remain about WeWork's business model of taking on long-term real estate leases and then renting out space in short-term rentals. Investors fear WeWork will have a hard time ever turning a profit, especially if the economy falters, leaving the company with an abundance of unoccupied office space. 
              Neumann is being replaced by two co-CEOS on an interim basis.
